summary: This pilot study investigates the effects of acute lower leg heating on blood flow and walking ability in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD). The research found that heating the lower leg for as little as 15 minutes significantly increased blood flow in the popliteal artery and improved the distance patients could walk in six minutes. These findings suggest that even short durations of lower leg heating can enhance both blood perfusion and exercise capacity in PAD patients, highlighting its potential as a beneficial intervention for this condition.
